channel.title: NPR Morning Edition
channel.description: Morning Edition takes listeners around the country and the world with multi-faceted stories and commentaries every weekday. Hosts Steve Inskeep, Leila Fadel, Michel Martin and A Martínez bring you the latest breaking news and features to prepare you for the day.

item.title: Law professor says stifling free speech is no way to commemorate Kirk's legacy
item.description: NPR speaks with Jonathan Turley, a law professor at George Washington University, about the conversation emerging around free speech in the wake of Charlie Kirk's death.

item.title: Suspect in Charlie Kirk's death could face the death penalty
item.description: Tyler Robinson, the man accused of fatally shooting conservative influencer Charlie Kirk, was charged with aggravated murder Tuesday, and prosecutors say they'll seek the death penalty.

item.title: Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter go on a new excellent adventure: 'Waiting for Godot'
item.description: In one of the most buzzed-about productions of the Broadway season, former Bill & Ted actors Keanu Reeves and Alex Winter unite once again in "Waiting for Godot."

item.title: Morning news brief
item.description: Prosecutors will seek the death penalty for the suspect in Charlie Kirk's death, President Trump is in the U.K. for a rare second state visit, FBI director returns to Capitol Hill.

item.title: Horse-drawn carriages and a royal salute for Trump's unprecedented second state visit
item.description: President Trump is in the United Kingdom for a rare second state visit that includes pageantry, policy and protests.

item.title: How China's growing industrial power buffers it from the trade war
item.description: China manufactures about one third of everything made in the world, and its industrial power is still expanding. Economist Dan Wang talks about the implications of its growth.

item.title: National Parks removing historical items Trump administration found 'disparaged' U.S.
item.description: Wednesday is the deadline for National Parks across the country to remove any signs, statues or memorials the Trump administration believes reflect negatively on the country.

item.title: Charlie Kirk's murder amplifies safety concerns among federal lawmakers
item.description: Two weeks before a potential government shutdown, House Republicans unveiled legislation to fund the government through Nov. 21. Included in that proposal -- $30 million for additional security.

item.title: Legal scholar talks about the Supreme Court's efforts to keep the Fed independent
item.description: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with legal scholar John Yoo about the Supreme Court's efforts to maintain the independence of the Federal Reserve Board.
